Identity.History: The lithobolos was developed in the early 4th century B.C. during Dionysius of Syracuse's expedition against the Carthaginians. Unlike many weapons at the time, the lithobolos was powered by a torsion mechanism. Torsion-based weapons can store and release energy more efficiently than tension-based weapons (like bows and crossbows). Compared to the oxybeles (Greek bolt shooter), the lithobolos was bigger, heavier, and more powerful and just had one single arm facing forward. One end of the arm was attached to the torsion mechanism. As the arm was rotated backwards, a bundle of sinew, skein, or fiber was twisted. A projectile was loaded and the lithobolos was fired. When the arm was released, the bundle unwound, launching the projectile at a 45-degree angle upward. The lithobolos could throw 150-pound stones hundreds of yards away. It was used to damage defensive structures such as walls or towers. Because catapults were bulky, they were carried in pieces and assembled on the battlefield. There are several recorded occasions of the Macedonians using all different kinds of siege weapons. For example, the army of Alexander the Great used lithobolos' during the Siege of Halicarnassus in 334 B.C.
